citeinfo.origin: New York City Department of City Planning
citeinfo.title: New York City Neighborhood Name Centroids

pubinfo.publish: City of New York Department of City Planning

citeinfo.othercit: The "New York: A City of Neighborhoods" files have undergone minor revisions since the 2006 release. The revisions include modification of neighborhood centroids positions, additions of neighborhood labels, or the removal of the neighborhood labels. Documentation of changes and additions to the 2009 version of "New York: A City of Neighborhoods" is located under Data Quality/Process Step Information sections of metadata.

idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 3; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.3.1.3000

descript.abstract: The New York City Neighborhood Names point file was created as a guide to New York City’s neighborhoods that appear in the “New York: A City of Neighborhoods” map poster and webpage. Best estimates of label centroids were established at a 1:1,000 scale, but are ideally viewed at a 1:50,000 scale.
descript.purpose: These points were created by the Department of City Planning as a guide to the locations of neighborhood labels found on the Department of City Planning's "New York: A City of Neighborhoods" poster and webpage.

idinfo.useconst: While all possible measures have been taken to ensure the accuracy of this data, the NYC Department of City Planning and the City of New York assume no responsibility for the accuracy of this data. All users should independently verify the accuracy of the data for their purposes.

procstep.procdesc: The "New York: A City of Neighborhoods" files have undergone minor revisions since the 2006 release. The revisions include modification of neighborhood centroids positions, additions of neighborhood labels, or the removal of the neighborhood labels. Documentation of changes and additions to the 2009 version of "New York: A City of Neighborhoods" is listed below.
The Queens neighborhood Jamaica Hill was changed to the preferred name Jamaica Hills.
Plumb Beach Gateway National Recreation Area in Brooklyn was removed from the neighborhood layer.

overview.dsoverv: These points were created as a guide to the locations of neighborhood labels found on the Department of City Planning's "New York: A City of Neighborhoods" poster and webpage. Best estimates of label centroids were established at a 1:1,000 scale, but are ideally viewed at a 1:50,000 scale.
overview.eaover: The "New York: A City of Neighborhoods" files have undergone minor revisions since the 2006 release. The revisions include modification of neighborhood centroids positions, additions of neighborhood labels, or the removal of the neighborhood labels. Documentation of changes and additions to the 2009 version of "New York: A City of Neighborhoods" is located under Data Quality/Process Step Information sections of metadata.

dataLineage.statement:
The “New York: A City of Neighborhoods” Neighborhood Names point file has undergone minor revisions since the 2010 release. These revisions include the addition of new neighborhood name labels, modification of existing neighborhood names centroids positions, deletion of neighborhood name labels, or updates to neighborhood names. A description of the changes is detailed below:
Additions: Nine new neighborhood names appear on the 2014 edition of the City of Neighborhoods Poster. These names include Allerton, Bronxdale, and Kingsbridge Heights in the Bronx; Erasmus in Brooklyn; Hudson Yards in Manhattan; Bayswater, Hammels, and Queensbridge in Queens; and Fox Hills in Staten Island.
Modified Positions: For increased positional accuracy, label centroids for the following neighborhood name labels were modified to coincide with the approximate center of the feature: Carroll Gardens and Cypress Hills in Brooklyn; Flushing in Queens; and Greenridge and Woodrow in Staten Island.
Deletions: Navy Yard in Brooklyn is now a place name and not a neighborhood name.
Name Updates: Four neighborhood names have been updated. South Corona in Queens is identified by Corona. The neighborhood located between Rockaway Park and Arverne in Queens CD 14 is identified as Rockaway Beach. Downtown Flushing, also in Queens, was changed to Flushing. High Bridge in the Bronx is now identified as Highbridge.
